Home → Events and activities → Skulduggery in Stowmarket

Skulduggery in Stowmarket

26 - 30 April 2018

Join us for Suffolk's newest crime writers' festival. Tickets on sale from Stowmarket Library and Mid Suffolk Tourist Information Centre or Ticketsource. £5 per author talk or £20 for all of Saturday's author talks.

Thursday 26 April

Ian Andrew: Fall Guys

1930

Ian Andrew will be talking about his Wright & Tran novels, the most recent of which is Fall Guys.

Friday 27 April

Pip Wright as Whistlecraft, 'The Rickinghall Poacher', followed by crime quiz with pizza supper

1900

Hear the true story of notorious Suffolk poacher George Ruffels, aka Joe Whistlecraft, from local historian and writer Pip Wright.

Saturday 28 April

Edward Wilson: The Suffolk Spy

1000–1050

Edward Wilson will be talking about his spy novels, set in the Cold War and featuring rather reluctant MI6 officer Catesby. Suffolk is at the core of these novels; Catesby hails from the county, and returns there at times of trouble.

Pauline Manders: Utterly Criminal

1100–1150

Pauline Manders will be talking about her Utterly crime series. This currently comprises seven books set in and around Suffolk and can be read as standalones.

Jacqueline Beard: Crime and My Ancestors

1200–1250

Jacqueline Beard will be talking about her Victorian murder mysteries, The Fressingfield Witch and Vote for Murder, murder mysteries based on true Suffolk crimes.

Mandy Morton and Nicola Upson in conversation

1400–1450

Nicola Upson and Mandy Morton will be giving us an insight into the writing of two very different series of crime novels.

Alison Bruce: Making Crime Pay

1500–1550

Alison Bruce will be talking about her work, including the DC Gary Goodhew novels, and her career as a crime writer.

Elly Griffiths: The Dark Angel

1600–1650

Elly Griffiths will be talking about her latest Dr Ruth Galloway novel, The Dark Angel.

Dr Tim Howes: How We Would Investigate the Murder of Maria Marten Today, followed by murder mystery with fish and chip supper

1830

Dr Tim Howes will be talking about how the infamous 1827 Red Barn murder of Maria Marten in Polstead would be investigated today.

Sunday 29 April

Children's activities with Kinetic and James Campbell

1000–1300

Children aged 8+ are invited to learn how to solve crimes with Kinetic and share their funny pet stories with The Funny Life of Pets author James Campbell.

Monday 30 April

Self-publishing workshop with Gipping Press

1000–1230

Budding authors are invited to learn all about the self-publishing process, including proofreading and bookbinding.
